user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_probe_bus:
```c
static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_probe_bus:
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
...
struct linux_driver {
	const char		*drv_name;
	const char		*mod_name;
	const char		*cls_name;
	struct sysfs_driver	*sdrv;
	int			(*dev_open)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					    struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_close)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_irq_ack)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev,
					     int irq);
	int			(*dev_dma_map)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg_in,
						int nents_in,
						struct metal_sg *sg_out);
	void			(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg,
						int nents);
}
...
static int metal_linux_probe_driver(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				    struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	char command[256];
	int ret;

	ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	/* Try probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* Try sudo probing the module and then open the driver. */
	if (!ldrv->sdrv) {
		ret = snprintf(command, sizeof(command),
			       "sudo modprobe %s > /dev/null 2>&1", ldrv->mod_name);
		if (ret >= (int)sizeof(command))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		ret = system(command);
		if (ret < 0) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING,
				  "%s: executing system command '%s' failed.\n",
				  __func__, command);
		}
		ldrv->sdrv = sysfs_open_driver(lbus->bus_name, ldrv->drv_name);
	}

	/* If all else fails... */
	return ldrv->sdrv ? 0 : -ENODEV;
}
...
static void metal_linux_bus_close(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		if (ldrv->sdrv)
			sysfs_close_driver(ldrv->sdrv);
		ldrv->sdrv = NULL;
	}

	sysfs_close_bus(lbus->sbus);
	lbus->sbus = NULL;
}
...
static int metal_linux_register_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	lbus->bus.name = lbus->bus_name;
	lbus->bus.ops  = metal_linux_bus_ops;
	return metal_bus_register(&lbus->bus);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in the provided code appear to reassign a function parameter (the pointer itself). Details:

- metal_linux_probe_bus: The parameter is 'struct linux_bus *lbus'. The function reads from lbus and writes to the object it points to (for example passing &lbus->bus to metal_linux_bus_close and assigning lbus->sbus only via sysfs_open_bus). It does not assign to the parameter variable lbus itself.

- metal_linux_probe_driver: Parameters are 'struct linux_bus *lbus' and 'struct linux_driver *ldrv'. The function assigns to fields of *ldrv (ldrv->sdrv) but does not reassign the pointer variables lbus or ldrv.

- metal_linux_bus_close: Parameter is 'struct metal_bus *bus'. The function converts that to a linux_bus pointer via a local variable (struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus)) and then modifies the object pointed to by lbus (and driver entries). It does not modify the parameter variable 'bus' itself.

- metal_linux_register_bus: Parameter is 'struct linux_bus *lbus'. The function modifies members of *lbus (lbus->bus.name, lbus->bus.ops) and calls metal_bus_register(&lbus->bus). It does not reassign the lbus pointer parameter.

- Struct definitions and function-pointer fields (struct linux_driver) are declarations and do not modify parameters. The function-pointer types themselves only declare signatures; no implementation shown that reassigns their parameters.

- The for_each_linux_driver macro operates with a local iterator (ldrv) and does not reassign the incoming pointer parameter in the shown uses.

Given the above, there are no instances in the provided code that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (no pointer parameter variable is reassigned). If implementations of called functions or the bodies of function-pointer callbacks (not provided here) reassign their pointer parameters, those would need to be inspected, but they are outside the supplied code fragments.
